citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
A 5yr old Frenchie, M, Fawn (Cody, ID# 9201 chip) had two loose teeth, a pre-molar with heavy tarter surrounding it on
the upper right side, and an upper incisor on the left that was at a sharp angle in the mouth. The gum appeared inflamed
and swollen around the affected tooth, and there was some buildup of tarter on other teeth. In April 2025 during the yearly
veterinary physical exams this dog was identified as requiring a dental at a grade of 3 out of 5 (worst), however the facility
has not made an appointment and provided timely treatment, which has resulted in loose teeth. While there was no
apparent infection or foul smelling odor in the mouth, due to the very loose teeth and tarter buildup the dental should have
been scheduled after the veterinarians yearly physical as was recommended.
The lack of timely dentals can cause unnecessary pain or discomfort to the regulated animal.
The licensee must use appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries, and the
availability of emergency, weekend, and holiday care;
To be corrected by: The licensee made an appointment with the attending veterinarian for the dental by the end of the
inspection exit interview.

There is a female Frenchie 'Tulip' (fawn, ID# 9273chip) that is in a primary enclosure that is too small in height as required
by the AWA regulations and standards. The top of the enclosure is only three inches above her head, where the
requirement is for a minimum of 6 inches above the head. For the past 3 weeks 'Tulip' was put in the smaller 2ft x 2ft x 2ft
cage due to her climbing out of her original 6ft x 3.5ft open topped primary enclosure, until they could come up with a way
to keep her from climbing out. She was let out daily in the facility, however the holding pen was too short per the
requirements.
A primary enclosure that is too small can cause stress or discomfort to the regulated animal.
The interior height of a primary enclosure must be at least 6 inches higher than the head of the tallest dog in the
enclosure when it is in a normal standing position.
To be corrected by: The issue was corrected by the end of the exit interview date. The licensee fixed the primary
enclosure to prevent the dog from climbing out. The dog was put back in a 6ft x 3.5ft open top area with a climbing
preventive measure in place.
This inspection was conducted with the facility representative and exit interview were conducted with both the licensee
and facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
A 5yr old Frenchie, M, Fawn (Cody, ID# 9201 chip) had two loose teeth, a pre-molar with heavy tarter surrounding it on 
the upper right side, and an upper incisor on the left that was at a sharp angle in the mouth. The gum appeared inflamed 
and swollen around the affected tooth, and there was some buildup of tarter on other teeth. In April 2025 during the yearly 
veterinary physical exams this dog was identified as requiring a dental at a grade of 3 out of 5 (worst), however the facility 
has not made an appointment and provided timely treatment, which has resulted in loose teeth. While there was no 
apparent infection or foul smelling odor in the mouth, due to the very loose teeth and tarter buildup the dental should have 
been scheduled after the veterinarians yearly physical as was recommended. 
 
The lack of timely dentals can cause unnecessary pain or discomfort to the regulated animal. 
 
The licensee must use appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries, and the 
availability of emergency, weekend, and holiday care; 
 
To be corrected by: The licensee made an appointment with the attending veterinarian for the dental by the end of the 
inspection exit interview. 
3.6(c)(1)(iii) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
There is a female Frenchie 'Tulip' (fawn, ID# 9273chip) that is in a primary enclosure that is too small in height as required 
by the AWA regulations and standards. The top of the enclosure is only three inches above her head, where the 
requirement is for a minimum of 6 inches above the head. For the past 3 weeks 'Tulip' was put in the smaller 2ft x 2ft x 2ft 
cage due to her climbing out of her original 6ft x 3.5ft open topped primary enclosure, until they could come up with a way 
to keep her from climbing out. She was let out daily in the facility, however the holding pen was too short per the 
requirements. 
 
A primary enclosure that is too small can cause stress or discomfort to the regulated animal. 
 
The interior height of a primary enclosure must be at least 6 inches higher than the head of the tallest dog in the 
enclosure when it is in a normal standing position.

To be corrected by: The issue was corrected by the end of the exit interview date. The licensee fixed the primary 
enclosure to prevent the dog from climbing out. The dog was put back in a 6ft x 3.5ft open top area with a climbing 
preventive measure in place. 
 
This inspection was conducted with the facility representative and exit interview were conducted with both the licensee 
and facility representative. 
 
 n
